a.g: Whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth exalts Allah, and He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.

It is He who expelled the ones who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture from their homes at the first gathering. You did not think they would leave, and they thought that their fortresses would protect them from Allah; but [the decree of] Allah came upon them from where they had not expected, and He cast terror into their hearts [so] they destroyed their houses by their [own] hands and the hands of the believers. So take warning, O people of vision.

Among people, there is one for whom the gaze of consideration (nazar al-i'tibar) is made easy, so he does not look at anything from the world of dominion (alam al-mulk) except that he crosses over with it to the world of sovereignty (alam al-malakut), and his crossing is called a lesson (ibrah). And the Truth (al-Haqq) has commanded it, saying: 'So take lesson (i'tabiru), O you of insight (uli al-absar).' {} And among them is one whose insight (basirah) is blinded, so he does not take lesson, and he is confined in the world of dominion (alam al-mulk) and the witnessed world (alam al-shahadah), and the gates of Hell will open to his confinement. And this confinement is filled with a fire whose nature is to rise upon the hearts (af'idah), except that between him and the perception of its pain is a veil (hijab). So when that veil is lifted by death, he perceives. And from this, Allah the Exalted manifested the truth upon the tongue of a people whom He made speak with the truth, and they said: 'Paradise and Hell are created, but the Blazing Fire (al-Jahim) is perceived once with a perception called the knowledge of certainty (ilm al-yaqin), and once with another perception called the eye of certainty (ayn al-yaqin). And the eye of certainty (ayn al-yaqin) does not occur except in the Hereafter, and the knowledge of certainty (ilm al-yaqin) may occur in this world, but for those who have fulfilled their share of the light of certainty (nur al-yaqin). Therefore, Allah the Exalted said: 'No! If you knew with the knowledge of certainty (ilm al-yaqin), you would see the Blazing Fire (al-Jahim).' {} That is, in this world. 'Then you will see it with the eye of certainty (ayn al-yaqin).' {} That is, in the Hereafter. So then, it has become clear that the sound heart (al-qalb al-salih) for the dominion of the Hereafter is only noble, like the sound person for the dominion of this world.

a.g: And if not that Allah had decreed for them evacuation, He would have punished them in [this] world, and for them in the Hereafter is the punishment of the Fire.
That is because they opposed Allah and His Messenger. And whoever opposes Allah - then indeed, Allah is severe in penalty.
Whatever you have cut down of [their] palm trees or left standing on their trunks - it was by permission of Allah and so He would disgrace the defiantly disobedient.

And what Allah restored [of property] to His Messenger from them - you did not spur for it [in an expedition] any horses or camels, but Allah gives His messengers power over whom He wills, and Allah is over all things competent.

And what Allah restored to His Messenger from the people of the towns - it is for Allah and for the Messenger and for [his] near relatives and orphans and the [stranded] traveler - so that it will not be a perpetual distribution among the rich from among you. And whatever the Messenger has given you - take; and what he has forbidden you - refrain from. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is severe in penalty.

For the poor emigrants who were expelled from their homes and their properties, seeking bounty from Allah and [His] approval and supporting Allah and His Messenger, [there is also a share]. Those are the truthful.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
Know that the one who harms is naturally hated, and if someone harms you, you cannot help but generally hate them. If a blessing is facilitated for them, you cannot help but dislike it for them until the good state of your enemy and their bad state become equal to you. Rather, you continuously perceive in the Soul (Nafs) a distinction between them, and Satan continuously contends with you towards envying them. But if that becomes strong in you until it incites you to manifest envy by word or deed such that it is known from your outward appearance through your voluntary actions, then you are an envious sinner with your envy. And if you completely restrain your outward appearance, yet in your inner self you desire the removal of the blessing and there is no aversion in your Soul (Nafs) to this state, then you are also an envious sinner, because envy is an attribute of the Heart (Qalb), not an attribute of action. Allah the Exalted said: "And they find in their chests no need of what they have been given" and He the Mighty and Majestic said: "They wish that you would disbelieve as they have disbelieved so you would be equal" and He said: "If good touches you, it distresses them." As for the action, it is backbiting and lying, and it is an act emanating from envy and is not the essence of envy. Rather, the place of envy is the Heart (Qalb), not the limbs. Indeed, this envy is not an injustice requiring seeking permission for it, but it is a sin between you and Allah the Exalted. And seeking permission is only required for the apparent causes upon the limbs. So if you restrain your outward appearance and compel along with that your Heart (Qalb) to aversion to what naturally emanates from it of desiring the removal of the blessing, until it is as if you detest your Soul (Nafs) for what is in its nature, so that aversion is from the side of the intellect in opposition to the inclination from the side of nature, then you have fulfilled what is obligatory upon you. And in most circumstances, no more than this enters under your choice. Explanation of the condemnation of miserliness. Allah the Exalted said: "And whoever is protected from the greed (Shuh) of his Soul (Nafs), then those are the successful ones." And He the Exalted said: "Those who are miserly and enjoin miserliness upon people and conceal what Allah has given them of His bounty." And He (peace be upon him) said: "Beware of greed (Shuh), for it destroyed those before you; it drove them to shed their blood and make lawful what was forbidden to them." And He (peace be upon him) said: "Three destructive things: obeyed greed (Shuh), followed desire (Hawa), and a person's admiration of himself." [78] And He (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed, Allah hates three: the old fornicator, the miserly one who reminds of favors, and the poor arrogant one." ğŸ“– Vol 2: Etiquette of Sama and Wajd
If you say: Why do these people not manifest spiritual state (Wajd) upon hearing the Quran, which is the Speech (Kalam) of Allah, while they manifest it upon hearing singing, which is the speech of poets? If that were truly from the grace (Lutf) of Allah the Exalted and not falsehood from the deception (Ghurur) of Satan, then the Quran would be more deserving of it than singing. We say: The true spiritual state (Wajd) is what arises from excessive love (Hubb) of Allah the Exalted and sincerity (Sidq) of His intention (Iradah) and longing (Shawq) for meeting Him, and that is also stirred by hearing the Quran. Rather, what is not stirred by hearing the Quran is love (Hubb) of creation and passion (Ishaq) for the created. Evidence for that is His saying the Exalted: 'Indeed, in the remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah do hearts find rest (Tatma'innu).' And His saying the Exalted: 'Verses (Mathani) at which the skins of those who fear their Lord shiver (Taqsha'irru), then their skins and their hearts soften (Talinna) at the remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah.' And everything that occurs in the soul (Nafs) following hearing is spiritual state (Wajd). So tranquility (Tuma'ninah), shivering (Iqsha'irrar), fear (Khashyah), and softening (Layn) of the heart (Qalb) - all of that is spiritual state (Wajd). And Allah the Exalted has said: 'The believers are only those who, when Allah is mentioned, their hearts tremble (Wajilat).' And He said: 'Had We sent down this Quran upon a mountain, you would have seen it humbled (Khashia'an), split asunder (Mutassadi'an) from fear (Khashyah) of Allah.' So trembling (Wajal) and humility (Khashu') are spiritual state (Wajd) from the category of states (Ahwal), even if not from the category of unveilings (Mukashafat), but they may become a cause for unveilings (Mukashafat) and alerts (Tanbihat).
